Expense Receipts with Corporate Cards: Implementation Activity The following activity will walk you through the process of creating the necessary entities for processing of expense receipts with corporate credit cards. The following activity is based on the U100 dataset. If you are using another dataset, or if any system settings have been changed in U100 , these changes can affect the workflow of the activity and the results of the processing. To avoid any issues, restore the U100 dataset to its initial state. Story Suppose that Jon Waite and Bill Owen (employees of the SweetLife company) can use a corporate credit card for charging their business expenses. Acting as an administrator, you need to create an account, payment method, and cash account for the company corporate card as well as to create the corporate card itself in the system. Configuration Overview For the purposes of this lesson, the Expense Management feature has been enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CA203000|CA203000]) Entry Types (CA203000) form, the BANKFEE entry type has been added. On the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees (EP203000) form, the accounts for Jon Waite and Bill Owen have been created. Process Overview To create a corporate card, you will first create a GL account on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form. You the will create a payment method for the card on the ([~/?ScreenId=CA204000|CA204000]) Payment Methods (CA204000) form. The GL account and payment method you will specify for a cash account, which you will create on the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202000|CA202000]) Cash Accounts (CA202000) form. Finally, you will create a corporate credit card on the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202500|CA202500]) Corporate Cards (CA202500) form. System Preparation Launch the Acumatica ERP website, and sign in as an administrator by using the admin username. Step 1: Creating a GL Account for a Corporate Card Create a GL account as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form, and on the form toolbar, click Add Row . In the new line, create an account with the following settings: Account : 29000 Account Class : OTHCURLIAB Type : Liability Description : Corporate Credit Card Post Option : Detail Save the new account. Step 2: Creating a Payment Method To create a payment method for the corporate credit card, do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA204000|CA204000]) Payment Methods (CA204000) form, and click Add New Record . In the Payment Method ID box, type CORPCC . In the Description box, type Corporate card payment method . Make sure the Use in AP check box is selected. Clear the following check boxes: Use in AR Because this payment method will not be used for customer payments. Require Remittance Information for Cash Account Remittance information is not required by this payment method for the related cash accounts. On the Settings for Use in AP tab, specify the following settings: Additional Processing : Not Required Payment documents created with this payment method do not require additional processing such as printing checks. Require Unique Payment Ref. (under Payment Settings ): Cleared The unique payment reference number is not required for each payment document created with this payment method. Save the payment method. Step 3: Creating a Cash Account Create a cash account as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202000|CA202000]) Cash Accounts (CA202000) form, and click Add New Record . In the Summary area, specify the following settings: Cash Account : 29000 Account : 29000 - Corporate Credit Card Requires Reconciliation : Selected Restrict Visibility with Branch : Cleared Use for Corporate Cards : Selected Reconciliation Numbering Sequence : CARECON - CA Reconciliation On the Payment Methods tab, click Add Row , and in the Payment Method column, select CORPCC . On the Entry Types tab, click Add Row , and in the Entry Type ID column, select BANKFEE . Save the created cash account. Step 4: Creating the Corporate Credit Card To create the corporate credit card, do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202500|CA202500]) Corporate Cards (CA202500) form. In the Name box, enter USD Corporate Card . In the Card Number box, enter the following card number: 7890 . In the Cash Account box , select 29000 - Corporate Credit Card. On the table toolbar, click Add Row , and select EP00000015 in the Employee ID column. Click Add Row again, and add EP00000003 - Jon Waite . On the form toolbar, click Save .

Expense Receipts with Corporate Cards: To Process Expense Receipts The following activity will walk you through the process of creating and processing of expense receipts with corporate cards. The following activity is based on the U100 dataset. If you are using another dataset, or if any system settings have been changed in U100 , these changes can affect the workflow of the activity and the results of the processing. To avoid any issues, restore the U100 dataset to its initial state. Story Suppose that engineers of the SweetLife company worked on a construction site on January 29, 2020, and it turned out that there were not enough screws. Jon Waite went to a construction store and bought a box of screws for $27 for which he paid with a company corporate card. He also bought a cup of coffee in a cafe near the store and paid $6 for it by the same corporate credit card. Then Jon took a taxi to return back for which he paid $10 by cash. Jon entered all expenses into the system and filed a claim for the reimbursement of expenses. The next day Bill Owen went to a meeting with the customer to discuss a project. He took a taxi and paid $25 by the corporate card. Configuration Overview For the purposes of this lesson, the Expense Management feature has been enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, the SCREW , MEAL , and TAXI non-stock items with the Expense type have been created. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202500|CA202500]) Corporate Cards (CA202500) form, the 000001 - USD Corporate Card corporate card has been added, as described in Expense Receipts with Corporate Cards: Implementation Activity. On the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees (EP203000) form, the accounts for Jon Waite and Bill Owen have been created. Process Overview First, you will create an expense receipt for paying a box of screws by Jon Waite on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301010|EP301010]) Expense Receipts (EP301010) form. You then will create an expense claim, which will also include expenses for taxi and coffee, on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301000|EP301000]) Expense Claim (EP301000) form. As the last step, you will create the second expense receipt for paying a taxi by Bill Owen on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301010|EP301010]) Expense Receipts form. System Preparation Do the following: Launch the Acumatica ERP website, and sign in as a project manager by using the owen username and the 123 password. In the info area, in the upper-right corner of the top pane of the Acumatica ERP screen, make sure that the business date in your system is set to 1/29/2020 . If a different date is displayed, click the Business Date menu button, and select 1/29/2020 from the calendar. For simplicity, in this lesson, you will create and process all documents in the system during this business date. Step 1: Creating the First Expense Receipt Do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301010|EP301010]) Expense Receipts (EP301010) form, and click Add New Record . The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301020|EP301020]) Expense Receipt (EP301020) form. In the Expense Item box, select SCREW . In the Claimed by box, select EP00000003 - Jon Waite . In the Branch box, select HEADOFFICE. On the Receipt Details tab, specify the following: Description : Box of screws Unit Cost : 27.00 Paid With : Corporate Card, Company Expense Corporate Card : 000001 - USD Corporate Card Save the receipt. Step 2: Processing an Expense Claim for the Expense Receipt While you are still on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301020|EP301020]) Expense Receipt (EP301020) form, click Actions Claim . The ([~/?ScreenId=EP301000|EP301000]) Expense Claim (EP301000) form opens. On the Expense Claim Details tab, notice the line for the box of screws. On the table toolbar, click Add Row , and specify the following settings in the new row: Expense Item : MEAL Description : Coffee Unit Cost : 6 Paid With : Corporate Card, Personal Expense Corporate Card : 000001 - USD Corporate Card Click Add Row , and specify the following settings in the new row: Expense Item : TAXI Description : Taxi Unit Cost : 10 Paid With : Personal Account Save the expense claim. On the form toolbar, click Actions Submit . Click Actions Release . On the Financial Details tab, review the documents have been generated for the claim. Step 3: Creating the Second Expense Receipt Do the following: In the info area, in the upper-right corner of the top pane of the Acumatica ERP screen, set the business date to 1/30/2020 . Open the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301010|EP301010]) Expense Receipts (EP301010) form, and click Add New Record . The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=EP301020|EP301020]) Expense Receipt (EP301020) form. In the Expense Item box, select TAXI . In the Claimed by box, make sure EP00000015 - Bill Owen is selected. In the Branch box, make sure HEADOFFICE is selected. On the Receipt Details tab, specify the following: Description : Taxi to the customer meeting Unit Cost : 25.00 Paid With : Corporate Card, Company Expense Corporate Card : 000001 - USD Corporate Card Save the receipt.

Expense Receipts with Corporate Cards: To Reconcile Bank Statements The following activity will walk you through the process of reconciliation of a bank statement. The following activity is based on the U100 dataset. If you are using another dataset, or if any system settings have been changed in U100 , these changes can affect the workflow of the activity and the results of the processing. To avoid any issues, restore the U100 dataset to its initial state. Story Suppose that engineers of the SweetLife company used a corporate card related to the New York Bank. At the end of January, 2020, the New York Bank sent a monthly statement and an accountant of the company reconciled this statement and processed a bill for the bank in the system. Configuration Overview For the purposes of this lesson, the standard set of features has been enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form, the 29000 - Corporate Credit Card account has been created. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202000|CA202000]) Cash Accounts (CA202000) form, the 29000 cash account linked to the GL account has been created. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CA202500|CA202500]) Corporate Cards (CA202500) form, the 000001 - USD Corporate Card corporate card has been added, as described in Expense Receipts with Corporate Cards: Implementation Activity. On the ([~/?ScreenId=AP303000|AP303000]) Vendors (AP303000) form, the NYBANK vendor account for the New York Bank has been created. On the GL Accounts tab, in the Expense Account box, the 29000 - Corporate Credit Card is selected for this account. Process Overview To reconcile a bank statement, you will first import bank transactions on the ([~/?ScreenId=CA306500|CA306500]) Import Bank Transactions (CA306500) form. You will match the bank transactions with the transactions in the system on the ([~/?ScreenId=CA306000|CA306000]) Process Bank Transactions (CA306000) form. You then will reconcile the bank statement on the ([~/?ScreenId=CA302000|CA302000]) Reconciliation Statements (CA302000) form. Finally, you will create a bill to pay the outstanding balance to the bank on the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. System Preparation Do the following: Download the January_Bank_Statement.csv file to your computer. Launch the Acumatica ERP website, and sign in as a project manager by using the owen username and the 123 password. Make sure you have completed the Expense Receipts with Corporate Cards: To Process Expense Receipts activity. In the info area, in the upper-right corner of the top pane of the Acumatica ERP screen, make sure that the business date in your system is set to 1/31/2020 . If a different date is displayed, click the Business Date menu button, and select 1/31/2020 from the calendar. For simplicity, in this lesson, you will create and process all documents in the system during this business date. Step 1: Importing Bank Transactions To import the bank transactions, do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA306500|CA306500]) Import Bank Transactions (CA306500) form, and click Add New Record . In the Cash Account box, select the 29000 - Corporate Credit Card account. In the Statement Date box, make sure 1/31/2020 is selected. In the Start Balance Date box, select 1/1/2020 . In the End Balance Date box, select 1/31/2020 . On the table toolbar, click Load Records from File and select the January_Bank_Statement.csv file that you have downloaded . Upload this file. In the Ending Balance box, specify -58.00 . Click Save on the form toolbar. Step 2: Matching Transactions in the System Do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA306000|CA306000]) Process Bank Transactions (CA306000) form. In the Cash Account box, select the 29000 - Corporate Credit Card account. On the form toolbar, click Auto-Match . Note that the system found documents with transactions that match the bank statement transactions. Click Process . Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA306500|CA306500]) Import Bank Transactions (CA306500) form. In the imported bank statement, note that the transactions have been processed and matched. Step 3: Reconciling a Bank Statement Reconcile the bank statement as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CA302000|CA302000]) Reconciliation Statements (CA302000) form, click Add New Record . In the Cash Account box, select the 29000 - Corporate Credit Card account. In the table, for both rows, select the Reconciled check box. In the Summary area, in the Statement Balance box, specify -33 . Clear the Hold check box. On the form toolbar, click Release . Step 4: Paying the Outstanding Balance to the Bank Create an AP bill for a bank: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form, and click Add New Record . In the Date box, select 1/31/2020 . In the Vendor box, select NYBANK . In the Description box, type Bank account settlement . On the Document Details tab, add a row with the following settings: Branch : HEADOFFICE Ext. Cost : 33.00 Account : 29000 (selected by default based on vendor settings) In the Summary area, clear the Hold check box. On the form toolbar, click Release . You can now pay the bill and process the related documents in the system.

row.PlainText: Working with Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders The topics of this chapter describe how to create a sales tax for purchases and process a purchase with a sales tax. In This Chapter Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: General InformationSales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Implementation ChecklistSales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Implementation ActivitySales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Related Report and Inquiry Forms
row.column: The topics of this chapter describe how to create a sales tax for purchases and process a purchase with a sales tax. ==In This Chapter== *[HelpRoot_Construction\Construction_Sales_Taxes_in_PO_GeneralInfo|Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: General Information] *:In your company’s AP bills, a sales tax is a tax paid by the company to its vendors as a part of an AP bill amount; in Acumatica ERP, the system calculates the sales tax in vendor documents automatically. *[HelpRoot_Construction\Construction_Sales_Taxes_in_PO_Implem_Checklist|Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Implementation Checklist] *:The following sections provide details you can use to ensure that the system is configured properly for creating an AP bill with a sales tax applied automatically, and to understand (and change, if needed) the settings that affect the processing workflow. *[HelpRoot_Construction\Construction_Sales_Taxes_in_PO_Implem_Activity|Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Implementation Activity] *:The following activity will walk you through the process of creatina a tax in the system. *[HelpRoot_Construction\Construction_Sales_Taxes_in_PO_Reports_Inquiries|Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Related Report and Inquiry Forms] *:This topic describes reports, inquiries, and forms you may review to gather information about AP bills.

Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: General Information In your company’s AP bills, a sales tax is a tax paid by the company to its vendors as a part of an AP bill amount; in Acumatica ERP, the system calculates the sales tax in vendor documents automatically. The system calculates taxes based on the following details specified in the document: The vendor The inventory IDs The total price of the inventory items The document date The system calculates the tax and taxable amounts by using the settings of each tax that corresponds to both the tax category of the specified inventory ID and the tax zone of the selected vendor. The system calculates the tax and taxable amounts for each line of the document or for the total document amount, depending on the settings of the applied tax (for details, see ). The system inserts the sales tax amount in the Tax Total box in the Summary area of the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. After you have released the document, the system creates the corresponding GL transaction and records these amounts to the appropriate GL accounts. Learning Objectives From reading the topics in this chapter and completing the process activity, you will learn how to do the following: Learn how to configure a sales tax Learn how to create an AP bill with a sales tax applied Release the AP bill and review the GL batch generated by the system Applicable Scenarios You create an AP bill with at least one sales tax to record a purchase subject to sales taxes.

Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Implementation Checklist The following sections provide details you can use to ensure that the system is configured properly for creating an AP bill with a sales tax applied automatically, and to understand (and change, if needed) the settings that affect the processing workflow. Implementation Checklist We recommend that before you initially create an AP bill with a sales tax applied automatically, you make sure the needed features have been enabled, settings have been specified, and entities have been created, as summarized in the following checklist. Form Criteria to Check ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form The tax-related accounts have been created. ([~/?ScreenId=TX206000|TX206000]) Tax Zones(TX206000) All needed tax zones have been created. ([~/?ScreenId=TX205500|TX205500]) Tax Categories (TX205500) The needed tax categories for all goods or services (which are represented as stock items and non-stock items in Acumatica ERP) that your company buys have been created. ([~/?ScreenId=TX205000|TX205000]) Taxes (TX205000) The sales taxes that your company uses have been created. The settings for the tax include the tax rate, the tax calculation method, the tax validity period (if any), and other required parameters. ([~/?ScreenId=AP303000|AP303000]) Vendors (AP303000) For each tax agency to which you will submit tax reports, a vendor account with the Vendor is Tax Agency check box selected have been created. The needed vendors and subcontractors in the Accounts Payable subledger have been created. Depending on the geographical location of the purchase transaction, different taxes can be applied to the document. To define which taxes are applied in the location of your vendor, the appropriate tax zone to each new or existing vendor has to be assigned. ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items(IN202500), ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) To calculate tax amounts in the documents in which you specify inventory IDs, the necessary stock items (for goods) and non-stock items (for services) have been created and associated with the appropriate tax category. Other Settings That Affect the Workflow The following settings and entities should be specified and defined, respectively: The following general ledger settings should be specified on the Posting Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=GL102000|GL102000]) General Ledger Preferences (GL102000) form: Make sure that the Automatically Post on Release check box is selected. This setting causes GL batches to be immediately posted after they are released. Clear the Generate Consolidated Batches check box to cause every AP transaction you enter to be posted as an individual batch to the general ledger. (When this check box is selected, the system consolidates into a single batch all transactions in the same currency posted to the same period for all documents being released.) The following accounts payable settings should be specified on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=AP101000|AP101000]) Accounts Payable Preferences (AP101000) form: Select the Hold Documents on Entry check box in the Data Entry Settings section. This setting gives the created AP bills the On Hold status. Clear the Require Vendor Reference check box in the Data Entry Settings section. This setting means that you do not have to enter a payment reference number in the Vendor Ref. box when creating an AP bill on the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. Make sure that the Automatically Post on Release check box is selected in the Posting Settings section. This setting causes AP bills to be automatically posted to the general ledger once they are released. With these settings specified and entities defined, users in your company can record and process documents in Acumatica ERP quickly and accurately, with a minimum of manual actions.

Sales Taxes in Purchase Orders: Implementation Activity The following activity will walk you through the process of creatina a tax in the system. The following activity is based on the U100 dataset. If you are using another dataset, or if any system settings have been changed in U100 , these changes can affect the workflow of the activity and the results of the processing. To avoid any issues, restore the U100 dataset to its initial state. Story The SweetLife company buys goods from its suppliers and pays the sales tax on these purchases (input tax). The rate of the sales tax is 8.875%. You need to configure a sales tax of the Input type in the system, which will be applied to AP documents. Configuration Overview For the purposes of this lesson, the standard set of features has been enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=TX205500|TX205500]) Tax Categories (TX205500) form, the TAXABLE category has been created. On the ([~/?ScreenId=TX206000|TX206000]) Tax Zones (TX206000) form, the NYSTATE tax zone has been created. On the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form, the 24100 - Tax Payable and 69000 - Tax Expenses accounts have been created. The 69000 - Tax Expenses account is included in the MATERIAL account group. Before configuring a sales tax in the production environment, you should know exactly which calculation method should be applied in the Calculation Rule box of the ([~/?ScreenId=TX205000|TX205000]) Taxes (TX205000) form (the Tax Settings tab). System Preparation Launch the Acumatica ERP website, and sign in as an administrator by using the admin username. Step: Creating a Sales Tax To create a sales tax, proceed as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=TX205000|TX205000]) Taxes (TX205000) form. On the form toolbar, click Add New Record , and specify the following settings on the Tax Settings tab: Tax ID : NYSALESTAX Description : New York sales tax Tax Type : Sales Calculation Rule : Exclusive Document-Level This setting means that the tax amount is calculated on the sum of the line amounts to which this tax is applied. Cash Discount : Does Not Affect Taxable Amount On the Tax Schedule tab, click Add Row on the table toolbar, and specify the following settings: Start Date : 1/1/2019 Tax Rate : 8.875 Reporting Group : Default Input Group Leave the default values in the remaining columns. Note that reporting group can have one of the following types: An Output group is specified for a tax that must be paid to a tax agency. An Input group is specified for a tax that can be claimed from a tax agency. On the Categories tab, click Add Row on the table toolbar, and select TAXABLE in the Tax Category column. On the Zones tab, click Add Row on the table toolbar, and select NYSTATE in the Tax Zone ID column. On the GL Accounts tab, specify the following settings: Tax Payable Account : 24100 - Tax Payable The Tax Payable account is the liability account that accumulates the tax amounts to be paid to the tax agency. The account is credited in the tax amount when taxable invoices are released. Tax Expense Account : 69000 - Tax Expenses The Tax Expenses account ( 69000 ) is included in the MATERIAL account group so that tax expenses are posted to the project specified for the AP document lines. Note that the Use Tax Expense Account check box is selected and non-editable because the Sales tax type has been selected on the Tax Settings tab. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

In this chapter, you will find topics about working with these reports in the system. ==In This Chapter== *[HelpRoot_Construction\Construction_Reports_GeneralInfo|Construction Reports: General Information] *:In this chapter, you will learn how to do the following:[anchor|#_66238f4e-cd01-4326-b4b2-333852c8c4cf]*Printand send substantiated billing reports and understand which information is included in them*Print and send work-in-progress reports and understand which information is included in them*Print and send American Institute of Architects (AIA) reports and understand which information is included in them*Print and send bonding reports and understand which information is included in them*Review the project life cycle and performance with the help of described reports *[HelpRoot_Construction\Construction_Reports_AIA|Construction Reports: AIA Reports] *:The AIA report consists of a signed summary sheet (AIA Document G702™–1992, Application and Certificate for Payment), followed by a schedule of values (G703™–1992, Continuation Sheet) that details the project tasks that has been completed and billed to date. Together, these documents are considered an application for payment, because the recipient will have a chance to review the schedule of values and either accept or dispute the billed amount. If they disagree, they will send back redlines so that the contractor can revise and resubmit the AIA billing application. The prepared document that includes both application sheet (G702) and continuation sheet (G703) is called AIA report

Construction Reports: General Information Acumatica ERP Construction Edition provides multiple construction reports that can be provided to customers. Learning Objectives In this chapter, you will learn how to do the following: Print and send substantiated billing reports and understand which information is included in them Print and send work-in-progress reports and understand which information is included in them Print and send American Institute of Architects (AIA) reports and understand which information is included in them Print and send bonding reports and understand which information is included in them Review the project life cycle and performance with the help of described reports Substantiated Billing Report In the construction industry, when contractors bill their customers, the customers may want to see proof of the costs. In this case, contractors need to provide supporting documentation along with the customer statement or invoice. Acumatica ERP Construction Editionincludes the following substantiated billing reports that you can use to retrieve costs for a specific billing period: ([~/?ScreenId=PM650000|PM650000]) Substantiated Billing (PM650000) The substantiated billing report provides a list of costs for the specified period with all transactions related to payable invoices, labor, and other project expenses grouped by the cost codes. ([~/?ScreenId=PM650050|PM650050]) Substantiated Billing - Consolidated (PM650050) In addition to the list of costs and transactions of a project for the specified period, the generated report includes all scanned or uploaded images of the PNG, JPG, JPEG, BMP, GIF, TIFF or TIF format attached to the corresponding cost records as separate pages. Also, the generated report file includes hyperlinks to the attached files that could not be included directly in the PDF file (such as, for example, encrypted PDF files). You can see these files by clicking the hyperlink and entering guest credentials into the Acumatica ERP sign-in page. WIP Report WIP (work-in-progress or work-in-process) is designed to track the progress of active jobs, as well as their financial performance. In addition to looking at the percentage of completion and the cost to complete, it also determines whether a job is overbilled or underbilled relative to its progress. When using the percentage-of-completion method for revenue recognition, companies include a WIP schedule with their financial statements. Acumatica ERP Construction Edition supports several versions of WIP reporting, providing necessary information, and with the recent inclusion of a b onding report, surety companies have visibility into a business’s performance. AIA Report The common construction billing format is known as AIA progress billing, named after the American Institute of Architects that produces its official forms. As a type of progress billing, AIA billing invoices (which are provided as AIA reports in Acumatica ERP Construction Edition) the customer based on the percentage of work completed for that billing period. For detailed description of the information included to AIA reports, see Construction Reports: AIA Reports. Bonding Report By using the ([~/?ScreenId=PM650500|PM650500]) Construction Bonding Report, you can create a report of work in progress for projects for a selected date range. This report can be used by management as well as external entities, such as bonding companies, to determine the financial health of projects. The report gives a bigger snapshot of all the projects in the system and provides management confidence. You could analyze how much is actually billed for the project compared to the percentage of the project completion. The ([~/?ScreenId=PM650500|PM650500]) Construction Bonding Report (PM650500) includes the following columns: Earned Revenue, Billed to Date, Unbilled Contract Amounts, as well as Cost Incurred to Date, Calculated Cost at Completion, Current Period Costs/Billings, as well as the prior year's Billings and Costs.

Construction Reports: AIA Reports The following sections describe the structure of the AIA report and the available report variations. Also, the sections provide information on and how you can reflect historic retainage and change order release, and how you can print the AIA report for billing the retainage solely. AIA Report Structure The AIA report consists of a signed summary sheet (AIA Document G702™–1992, Application and Certificate for Payment), followed by a schedule of values (G703™–1992, Continuation Sheet) that details the project tasks that has been completed and billed to date. Together, these documents are considered an application for payment, because the recipient will have a chance to review the schedule of values and either accept or dispute the billed amount. If they disagree, they will send back redlines so that the contractor can revise and resubmit the AIA billing application. The prepared document that includes both application sheet (G702) and continuation sheet (G703) is called AIA report In AIA report, application sheet along with continuation sheet provide convenient and complete forms on which the contractor can apply for payment and the architect can certify that payment is due. The application require the contractor to show the status of the contract sum to date, including the total amount of the work completed and stored to date, the amount of retainage (if any), the total of previous payments, a summary of change orders, and the amount of current payment requested. The continuation sheet breaks the contract sum into portions of the work in accordance with a schedule of values prepared by the contractor as required by the general conditions. The AIA report does not publish a standard schedule of values form. AIA report serves as both the contractor’s application and the architect’s certification. Using AIA report helps to expedite payment and reduces the possibility of errors. If the application is properly completed and acceptable to the architect, the architect’s signature certifies to the owner that a payment in the amount indicated is due to the contractor. The form also allows the architect to certify an amount different than the amount applied for, with explanation provided by the architect. Configuring AIA Report Parameters for a Project Based on project requirements, for a particular project, you define the format in which the AIA report will be prepared. To prepare the printable version of the AIA report, you select the line with the needed pro forma invoice in the table on the Invoices tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=PM301000|PM301000]) Projects (PM301000) form, and click AIA Report on the table toolbar; you can instead open the pro forma invoice on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM307000|PM307000]) Pro Forma Invoices (PM307000) form and click the AIA Report button on the form toolbar. By default, a newly created project has the AIA Level setting set to Summary and the Show Quantity in AIA Report check box cleared. When you create an AIA report for such a project, the standard AIA report ( ([~/?ScreenId=PM644000|PM644000]) AIA Report (PM644000) ) with continuation sheet lines grouped by project tasks is prepared. If you need to include quantities to the lines of the continuation sheet of the AIA report prepared for a project, in the settings of the project on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM301000|PM301000]) Projects form, select the Show Quantity in AIA Report check box, so that the system will create the ([~/?ScreenId=PM644500|PM644500]) AIA Report with Quantity (PM644500) report. To list the continuation sheet lines without grouping by project tasks (that is, as they are presented in the corresponding pro forma invoice), select Detail in the AIA Level box. Date-Sensitive Data in AIA Reports AIA reports are date-sensitive, which means that the particular amounts are included or not included to the report based on the report date; this in turn could lead to differences between calculation of amounts in AIA reports and financial calculations in other documents. The date on which the AIA report is prepared affects the following amounts in AIA application sheet: To the Net Change by Change Orders amount, the system includes only change orders that have the approval date less then the invoice date of the pro forma invoice, for which the AIA report is being prepared. To the Retainage amount, the system does not include the retainage that have been released before creation of the pro forma invoice for which the AIA report is being prepared (that is, the invoice date of the retainage invoice is less then the invoice date of the pro forma invoice). To the Less Previous Certificates for Payment amount, the system includes the sum of the retainage amount that have been released before the date of the previous application (that is, the invoice date of the retainage invoice is less then or equal to the invoice date of the previous pro forma invoice prepared for the project). To the Current Payment Due amount, the system includes the amounts of retainage invoices that have been prepared since the last application (that is, the invoice date of the retainage invoice is greater then the invoice date of the previous pro forma invoice and is less then or equal to the invoice date of the pro forma invoice for which the AIA report is prepared). The date on which the AIA report is prepared affects the following amounts in AIA continuation sheet: To the amounts in the Change Orders and Change Qty. columns, the system includes only change orders that have the approval date less then the invoice date of the pro forma invoice, for which the AIA report is being prepared. To the Retainage Held , the system does not include the retainage that have been released before creation of the pro forma invoice for which the AIA report is being prepared (that is, the invoice date of the retainage invoice is less then the invoice date of the pro forma invoice). AIA Reports for Released Retainage If the Retainage Support feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can create AIA report that will include the retainage that has been fully or partially released (depending on the date for which the AIA report is prepared), or all released retainage at the end of the project. You can prepare an AIA report for released retainage if the following conditions are met: The retainage in the financial period for which the report is being prepared has been released. The zero pro forma invoice has been created, and the invoice date of the zero pro forma invoice is the same as or later than the date of the corresponding AR retainage invoice. A zero pro forma invoice could be created only if in the billing rule assigned to a project task, the Create Lines with Zero Amounts check box is selected in the progress billing step on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM207000|PM207000]) Billing Rules (PM207000) form. You run project billing for a project with a pending invoice amount of zero to prepare a zero pro forma invoice. If all conditions are met, to prepare the printable version of the AIA report, you select the line with the zero pro forma invoice in the table on the Invoices tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=PM301000|PM301000]) Projects (PM301000) form, and click AIA Report on the table toolbar (or open the zero pro forma invoice and click the AIA Report button on the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=PM307000|PM307000]) Pro Forma Invoices (PM307000) form). Depending on the date for which the AIA report is prepared, the report will include the retainage that has been fully or partially released in the middle of the project, or all released retainage at the end of the project. In the prepared report, the total retainage amount on the cover sheet of the AIA report is calculated as the sum of the held retainage amounts on the AIA continuation sheet.

You can enter the needed custom attributes for each compliance document type and define your custom statuses for compliance documents. Each organization could have their proper attributes for compliance documents. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_30_40_00|Daily Field Report] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ304000|PJ304000]) *:You can use this form to create, view, and edit a daily field report. You can also create a new request for information or project issue for drawing logs selected in the table. You can download a ZIP file with all the files of the selected drawing logs. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_50_40_00|Load Daily Field Report Weather Conditions] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ504000|PJ504000]) *:You can use this form to get weather conditions from the API of the integrated weather service for the selected daily field reports or for all daily field reports. You can use this form to create, view, and edit a photo log. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_10_30_00|Photo Log Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ103000|PJ103000]) *:You use this form to establish settings for photo logs. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_40_50_00|Photo Logs] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ405000|PJ405000]) *:You can use this form to view all the photo logs that have been created in the system or the photo logs related to a specific project or project task; you can also list photo logs by date range. On this form, you can view the main photo of the photo log selected in the table. *[HelpRoot_Construction\CL_50_20_00|Print/Email Lien Waivers] ([~/?ScreenId=CL502000|CL502000]) *:On this form, you can print or send lien waivers by email. *[HelpRoot_Construction\SC_50_30_00|Print/Email Subcontracts] ([~/?ScreenId=SC503000|SC503000]) *:On this form, you can print the all subcontracts or those you select or send the needed subcontracts by email. On this form, you track and report all activities related to the selected project issue. If needed, you can create a request for information or change request based on the selected issue. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_20_10_00|Project Management Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ201000|PJ201000]) *:You use this form to add, view, edit, and delete the project management classes that are used in project issues and requests for information. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_10_10_00|Project Management Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ101000|PJ101000]) *:On this form, you specify the general settings for project issues, requests for information, daily field reports, and other aspects of project management. Also, you can specify settings for copies of daily field report and for integration with weather services. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PM_GI_00_25|Project Summary] *:The inquiry lists the cost budget amounts, revenue budget amounts and change order amounts grouped by project. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PM_GI_00_35|Project Transaction Inquiry] *:This inquiry contain detail information on all project transactions that have been processed in the system. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_30_10_00|Request for Information] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ301000|PJ301000]) *:You can use this form to create, view, and edit a request for information. On this form, you track and report all activities related to the requests for information discovered during construction works. Based on a request for information, another request for information or change request may be created. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PM_GI_00_40|Revised Contract vs Approved CO] *:This inquiry provides information about total amount of revenue change order approved for the projects and the revised budgeted amounts for these projects. *[HelpRoot_Construction\SC_30_10_00|Subcontracts] ([~/?ScreenId=SC301000|SC301000]) *:On this form, you can view existing subcontracts, create new subcontracts, and add lines to subcontracts. Once a subcontract has been saved, it can be approved, rejected, or canceled by any employee assigned to review this subcontract. *[HelpRoot_Construction\SC_10_10_00|Subcontracts Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=SC101000|SC101000]) *:You use this form to provide the general settings for the Subcontracts module, such as numbering sequences for subcontracts, validation requirements for subcontracts, approval and mailing settings, and the list of attributes for subcontracts. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PJ_30_60_00|Submittals] ([~/?ScreenId=PJ306000|PJ306000]) *:On this form, you can view existing submittals, create new submittals, and work with existing submittals. *[HelpRoot_Construction\PM_GI_00_15|Vendor Commitment Details] *:The inquiry lists open project commitment (purchase orders and subcontracts associated with projects) details. You can filter the list of vendor commitment details by using selection criteria. For instance, you can display only commitments associated with a specific project, vendor, inventory item, or date range (or any combination of these criteria).

Cost Projection Form ID: (PM305000) ([~/?ScreenId=PM305000|PM305000])This form is available only if the Construction and Construction Project Management features are enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. You use this form to create revisions of cost projections for a project. Cost projections are used for tracking the project costs during the project completion in comparison to the initially estimated costs. Form Toolbar The form toolbar includes standard and form-specific buttons. For the list of standard buttons, see Form Toolbar. The form-specific buttons are listed below. Button Description Actions Provides the following menu commands, which you can click to invoke actions: Refresh Budget : Updates the budgeted values in the cost budget lines with the most recent values from the project, and recalculates projected values based on the budgeted values according to mode specified in the cost projection lines: For the lines with Auto mode, the system recalculates all projected values. For the lines with Manual Cost mode, the system recalculates the Projected Quantity to Complete and Projected Quantity at Completion . For the lines with Manual Quantity mode, the system recalculates the Projected Cost to Complete and Projected Cost at Completion . Approve : Changes the status of the cost projection from Pending Approval to Open . This action is available if the Approval Workflow feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form and cost projection approval is configured on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM101000|PM101000]) Projects Preferences (PM301000). Reject : Changes the status of the cost projection from Pending Approval to Rejected . This action is available if the Approval Workflow feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form and cost projection approval is configured on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM101000|PM101000]) Projects Preferences. Release : Releases the cost projection revision and updates the Projected Quantity to Complete , Projected Quantity at Completion , Projected Cost to Complete , Projected Cost at Completion and Completed (%) values in the cost budget lines of a project. The cost projection revision is assigned the Released status. Copy Revision Opens the Copy Revision dialog box, where you can create a copy of the cost projection revision and specify the ID of the new revision. Copy Revision Dialog Box You use this dialog box to create a new cost projection revision for the project by copying the existing one. Element Description New Revision The identifier of the new revision of the cost projection. The length of the identifier, which can consist of only alphanumeric characters and spaces, can be 10 or fewer characters. Refresh Budget A check box that indicates (if selected) that when creating a new cost projection revision the system should add the cost budget lines with the latest budgeted values. If the check box is cleared, the system will create a new cost projection revision with the budgeted values from the revision being copied. Copy Notes A check box that indicates (if selected) that the system should copy to the newly created cost projection revision any notes attached to the current cost projection revision. Copy Files A check box that indicates (if selected) that the system should copy to the newly created cost projection revision any files attached to the current cost projection revision. This dialog box has the following button. OK Creates a new revision of the cost projection as a copy of the selected revision, and closes the dialog box. Cancel Cancels the creation of a copy of the selected cost projection revision, and closes the dialog box. Summary Area You can use the elements in this area to add a new revision of the cost projection or select an existing cost projection revision for the particular project and view its details. Element Description Project ID The unique identifier for the project for which the cost projection revision is created. Revision The revision identifier of the cost projection. If you are creating a new revision, enter an alphanumeric identifier, which must be unique within the project. To view an existing revision, select the revision identifier after you select the project identifier. The length of the identifier, which can consist of only alphanumeric characters and spaces, can be up to 10 characters. Status The status of the cost projection revision, which can be one of the following: On Hold : The user can edit the cost projection revision but cannot release it. Pending Approval : The cost projection revision has been taken off hold (that is, the status was assigned when the Hold check box was cleared for the cost projection revision). This status is available only if the Approval Workflow feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form and cost projection revision approval is configured on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM101000|PM101000]) Projects Preferences (PO101000) form. Rejected : The system assigns this status to the cost projection revision if the employee who was assigned to approve the cost projection revision has rejected it. This status is available only if the Approval Workflow feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form and cost projection approval is configured on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM101000|PM101000]) Projects Preferences form. Open : The system assigns this status to the cost projection revision if the employee who was assigned to approve the cost projection revision has approved it. If no approval is configured for cost projections, the system assigns this status to the cost projection revision when the Hold check box is cleared. Released : The cost projection revision has been released and cannot be edited. Hold A check box that you select to indicate that the cost projection should have the On Hold status. When you clear the check box, the system gives the cost projection the Open status thus indicating that the cost projection is ready to processing, or the Pending Approval status if cost projection approval is configured on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM101000|PM101000]) Projects Preferences form. Description The description of the cost projection. Class The cost projection class of the cost projection revision which is defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM203500|PM203500]) Cost Projection Classes (PM203500) form and defines the detail level of the cost projection. Revision Date The date of creating a cost projection revision. Budgeted section Total Cost to Complete The remainder of the budgeted cost by all cost budget lines added on the Details tab calculated as the sum of the Cost to Complete amounts. Total Cost at Completion The budgeted final cost at the moment of project completion by all cost budget added on the Details tab calculated as the sum of the Cost at Completion amounts. Projected section Total Cost to Complete The projected remainder of the budgeted cost by all cost budget lines added on the Details tab calculated as the sum of the Projected Cost to Complete amounts. Total Cost at Completion The projected final cost at the moment of project completion by all cost budget added on the Details tab calculated as the sum of the Projected Cost at Completion amounts. Details Tab On this tab, you can add the cost budget lines of the project to the cost projection revision. Table Toolbar The table toolbar includes standard buttons and buttons that are specific to this table. For the list of standard buttons, see Table Toolbar. The table-specific buttons are listed below. Button Description Select Budget Lines Opens the Select Budget Lines dialog box, where you can select the cost budget lines to be added to the cost projection revision. View Commitment Details Opens the ([~/?ScreenId=PM306000|PM306000]) Commitments (PM306000) form in a pop-up window. This form shows the list of commitments that correspond to the selected cost budget line. View Transactions Opens the ([~/?ScreenId=PM304000|PM304000]) Project Transactions (PM304000) form in a pop-up window. This form shows the list of project transactions that correspond to the selected cost budget line. History Opens the History window, where you can review the history of cost projection revisions of the same cost projection class for the selected cost budget line. Select Budget Lines Dialog Box You use this dialog box to add the cost budget lines of the project to the current cost projection revision. Element Description Included An unlabeled check box that you select to include this purchase order in the current purchase receipt or return. Project Task The project task to which the cost budget line relates. Inventory ID The stock or non-stock inventory item that is associated with the cost budget line. Cost Code The cost code that is associated with the cost budget line. Account Group The expense account group of the cost budget line. Description The description entered for the cost budget line. UOM The unit of measure of the cost budget line. Original Budgeted Quantity The original budgeted quantity of the cost budget line. Original Budgeted Amount The original budgeted amount of the cost budget line. Budgeted CO Quantity The total quantity of the lines of released change orders that are associated with the cost budget line. Budgeted CO Amount The total amount of the lines of released change orders that are associated with the cost budget line. Revised Committed Quantity The total revised quantity of the commitments that are associated with the cost budget line. Revised Committed Amount The total revised amount of the commitments that are associated with the cost budget line. Committed Received Quantity The total received quantity of the commitments that are associated with the cost budget line. Committed Invoiced Quantity The total invoiced quantity of the commitments that are associated with the cost budget line. Committed Invoiced Amount The total invoiced amount of the commitments that are associated with the cost budget line. Committed Open Quantity The total open quantity of the commitments that are associated with the cost budget line. Actual Quantity The total quantity of the released project transactions that correspond to the cost budget line. Actual Amount The total amount of the released project transactions that correspond to the cost budget line. Actual + Open Committed Amount The sum of the actual amount and committed open amount for the cost budget line. The dialog box has the following buttons. Add Lines Adds the included cost budget lines to the cost projection revision. Add Lines & Close Adds the included cost budget lines to the cost projection revision and closes the dialog box. Close Closes the dialog box without making additions to the cost projection revision. History Window The table toolbar in the window includes only standard buttons. For the list of standard buttons, see Tables. Column Description Revision The identifier of the cost projection revision. Revision Date The date of the cost projection revision. Budgeted Quantity The budgeted quantity of the cost budget line in the revision of cost projection. Budgeted Cost The budgeted cost of the cost budget line in the revision of cost projection. Actual + Committed Open Quantity The sum of the actual quantity and committed open quantity of the cost budget line in the revision of cost projection. Actual + Committed Open Cost The sum of the actual cost and committed open cost of the cost budget line in the revision of cost projection. Quantity to Complete The remainder of the budgeted quantity of the cost budget line that is currently available for completion in the revision of cost projection. This quantity is calculated by the following formula: Quantity to Complete = Budgeted Quantity – (Actual Quantity + Revised Committed Quantity – Invoiced Committed Quantity) Cost to Complete The remainder of the budgeted cost of the cost budget line that is currently available for completion in the revision of cost projection. This cost is calculated by the following formula: Cost to Complete = Budgeted Cost – (Actual Cost + Revised Committed Cost – Invoiced Committed Cost) Projected Quantity to Complete The projected remainder of the budgeted quantity for the cost budget line in the revision of cost projection, which by default is equal to the Quantity to Complete . Projected Cost to Complete The projected remainder of the budgeted cost for the cost budget line in the revision of cost projection, which by default is equal to the Cost to Complete . Table Columns Column Description Account Group The expense account group of the cost budget line. Cost Task The project task to which the cost budget line relates. Inventory ID The stock or non-stock inventory item that is associated with the cost budget line. Description The description entered for the cost budget line. UOM The unit of measure of the cost budget line. Budgeted Quantity The budgeted quantity of the cost budget line specified in the project. Budgeted Cost The budgeted cost of the cost budget line specified in the project. Actual + Committed Open Quantity The sum of the actual quantity and committed open quantity of the cost budget line specified in the project. Actual + Committed Open Cost The sum of the actual cost and committed open cost of the cost budget line specified in the project.. Quantity to Complete The remainder of the budgeted quantity of the cost budget line that is currently available for completion. This quantity is calculated by the following formula: Quantity to Complete = Budgeted Quantity – (Actual Quantity + Revised Committed Quantity – Invoiced Committed Quantity) Cost to Complete The remainder of the budgeted cost of the cost budget line that is currently available for completion. This cost is calculated by the following formula: Cost to Complete = Budgeted Cost – (Actual Cost + Revised Committed Cost – Invoiced Committed Cost) Projected Quantity to Complete The projected remainder of the budgeted quantity for the cost budget line, which by default is equal to the Quantity to Complete ; the system recalculates this quantity if you change any other projected value in the line and the recalculation mode in the Mode box in the line is set to Auto or Manual Cost . If you override this value, the corresponding values in the cost budget line will be recalculated based on the recalculation mode of the line. Projected Cost to Complete The projected remainder of the budgeted cost for the cost budget line, which by default is equal to the Cost to Complete ; the system recalculates this cost if you change any other projected value in the line and the recalculation mode in the line is set to Auto or Manual Quantity . If you override this value, the corresponding values in the cost budget line will be recalculated based on the recalculation mode of the line. Projected Quantity at Completion The projected final quantity at the moment of project completion for the cost budget line. By default, this quantity is calculated by the following formula: Projected Quantity at Completion = Projected Quantity to Complete + Actual Quantity + Revised Committed Quantity – Invoiced Committed Quantity If you override this value, the corresponding values in the cost budget line will be recalculated based on the recalculation mode of the line. Projected Cost at Completion The projected final cost at the moment of project completion for the cost budget line. By default, this cost is calculated by the following formula: Projected Cost at Completion = Projected Cost to Complete + Actual Cost + Revised Committed Cost – Invoiced Committed Cost If you override this value, the corresponding values in the cost budget line will be recalculated based on the recalculation mode of the line. Projected Completed (%) The projected percentage of completion for the cost budget line. By default, this percentage is calculated by the following formula: Projected Completed (%) = (Budgeted Cost – Projected Cost to Complete) / Budgeted Cost * 100% If you override this value, the corresponding values in the cost budget line will be recalculated based on the recalculation mode of the line. Mode The mode that specifies how the amounts and quantities are recalculated for the cost budget line. The following options are available: Auto : If specified, the system automatically recalculates projected quantities and costs if any other projected value in the cost budget line is being changed. Manual : If specified, the system do not recalculate projected quantities and costs if any other projected value in the cost budget line is being changed. Manual Quantity : If specified, the system automatically recalculates projected costs if any other projected value in the cost budget line is being changed; the Projected Quantity to Complete and Projected Quantity at Completion values are preserved. Manual Cost : If specified, the system automatically recalculates projected quantities if any other projected value in the cost budget line is being changed; the Projected Cost to Complete and Projected Cost at Completion values are preserved. Approval Details Tab This tab, which is available only if the Approval Workflow feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, displays information about the approval history of cost projection revisions. The cost projection revision is automatically assigned for approval when taken off hold, in accordance with the approval map specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM101000|PM101000]) Projects Preferences (PM101000) form; if no map is specified on that form, cost projection revision do not require approval. Authorized users approve or reject cost projection revisions by using the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals (EP503010) form. The table toolbar includes only standard buttons. For the list of standard buttons, see Table Toolbar. Column Description Assignee ID The employee ID of the person in the specified workgroup who is authorized to approve the cost projection revision. Assigned To The name of the person in the specified workgroup who is authorized to approve the cost projection revision. Workgroup The workgroup assigned to approve the cost projection revision . Approver By (ID) The employee ID of the person who actually approved the cost projection revision. Approved By The name of the employee in the specified workgroup who actually approved the cost projection revision. Approval Date The date when the cost projection revision was approved. Status The status of the cost projection revision after the approver was assigned or the approval was performed. Reason The reason the cost projection revision has been approved or rejected.
